Award.AwardTitle: Summer Conference on Topology and its Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support for the 33rd Summer Conference on Topology and its Applications, to be held July 17-20, 2018, at Western Kentucky University. This conference series showcases advances in topology and applications to areas such as algebra, analysis, and computer science. Special sessions in topology applied to materials properties and in knot theory applied to the physical science will provide opportunities to foster interdisciplinary collaborations. To encourage scientific awareness in the community, Michael Kosterlitz, 2016 Nobel Laureate in Physics, will deliver a public lecture on applications of topology in physics. Each of the seven special sessions will include presentations by students, early career researchers, and established scholars, and will encourage participation from women and scholars from underrepresented groups. The peer-reviewed journal Topology Proceedings will have a special issue for papers presented at this conference.

The conference will have special sessions in Topology in Analysis and Topological Algebras (dedicated to W. W. Comfort), Set-theoretic Topology, Topological Methods in Geometric Group Theory, Dynamical Systems and Continuum Theory, Asymmetric Topology, Applications of Knot Theory to Physical Sciences, and The Interplay of Topology and Materials Properties. To foster the sharing of ideas across the sub-disciplines, each session will have a plenary speaker. Besides the applications within mathematics included in all sessions, these sessions will include interdisciplinary applications to physics (Materials Properties), biology (Knot Theory), and computer science (Asymmetric Topology). Further details are available at the conference website:

https://sites.google.com/site/summertopology2018/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 33rd Summer Conference on Topology and its Applications was held July 17-20, 2018.   The purpose of the conference was to bring together researchers in all stages of their careers to exchange ideas, foster their development in their specialties, and introduce them to new techniques and applications outside their specialties. 

The conference included 1-hour addresses by 25 distinguished researchers.  Including contributed talks, there were 174 presentations.  The welcome reception, coffee breaks and lunches provided opportunities for researchers to establish contacts, pose questions, and share their ideas further.

There were 181 registered participants from 24 countries.  In addition to a plenary talk, 2016 Physics Nobel Laureate Michael Kosterlitz delivered a public lecture on his route to the Nobel prize for his topological works.   Colin Adams gave a plenary workshop on multicrossing numbers of knots.

Some of the highlights of the seven special sessions are given below. 

 

Topology in Analysis and Topological Algebras (dedicated to W. W. Comfort)

Jan van Mill (Amsterdam) opened the conference with some memories of W. W. Comfort and then spoke on dimension theory. Salvador Hern?ndez (Castell?n, Spain) presented an overview of W. W. Comfort?s contributions to the study of Bohr topology.  Wieslaw Kubis (Prague) spoke about universal topological vector spaces, and Mat?as Raja (Murcia, Spain) discussed descriptive compact spaces. Krzysztof Piszczek (Poznan, Poland) gave results on amenability in various categories, and Sergey Antonyan (UNAM, Mexico) discussed free proper actions of Lie groups.  With 28 contributed talks, this was the largest session.

 

Set-Theoretic Topology

Lyubomyr Zdomskyy (Wien) discussed combinatorial properties of open covers, dense sets, and forcing.   Andrea Medini (Wein) spoke on homogeneous spaces and Wadge theory, and Lynne Yengulalp (U. Dayton) presented some completeness properties and topological games.  At least a quarter of the 16 contributed talks were by students or early career researchers. 

 

Topological Methods in Geometric Group Theory

Craig Guilbault (U. Wisconsin Milwaukee) presented some history, applications, and recent progress on group boundaries.  Emily Stark (Technion, Israel) spoke on Cannon-Thurston maps in non-positive curvature, and Chris Hruska (U. Wisconsin Milwaukee) presented results on virtual Kleinian groups.  Among the contributed talks, Rebecca Winarski presented a topological solution to the twisted rabbit problem, and Rose Morris-Wright discussed CAT(0) cube complexes associated with Artin groups. 

 

Dynamical Systems and Continuum Theory

Piotr Oprocha (AGH Univ. Krakow) discussed results on minimal dynamical systems and topological spaces that admit them. Lori Alvin (Bradley U.) examined the relationship between the behavior of the dynamics of a unimodal map and adding machine. Paula Ivon Vidal Escobar (UNAM Moreila, Mexico) presented conditions when an arc-continua can be obtained by generalized inverse limits. Eight different countries were represented by the presenters.

 

Asymmetric Topology

Jorge Picado (Coimbra, Portugal) compared normality and extremal disconnectedness.  Gerald Beer (California State Univ., Los Angeles) gave results on the oscillation of a function, and Tom Vroegrijk (T.U. Delft) presented some special quasi-uniform spaces.  Among the contributed talks, Natalia Jonard-Perez (UNAM, Mexico) discussed local compactness of asymmetric normed spaces, Maria Manuel Clementino (Coimbra, Portugal) discussed weak Cartesian closedness, and Collins Aburo Agyingi (North-West University, South Africa) presented results on quasi-metric spaces.  The 18 speakers in this session came from 8 different countries.

 

Applications of Knot Theory to Physical Sciences

In addition to the plenary workshop lecture by Colin Adams (Williams College) on multi crossing numbers there were two semi plenary talks by Dorothy Buck (U. of Bath, UK) on knots in replicating DNA, and X. Jin (Xiamen U, China) on zeros of Jones polynomials of graphs.

With 25 contributed speakers, this was a large session, attracting participants working in applied knot theory from all across the world (Japan, China, Canada, United Kingdom and Germany). In addition, there were several graduate students in attendance.

 

The Interplay of Topology and Materials Science

In addition to his public lecture, Nobel laureate Michael Kosterlitz (Brown U.) spoke on topological defects and phase transitions.  David Nelson (Harvard U.) discussed perforations and the crumpling of free-standing graphene.  Eugene Mele (U. Penn.) gave results on anomalous velocity and geometry in condensed matter, Ivan Smalyukh (U. Colorado, Boulder) spoke on topological solitons and other knots in soft matter and Randy Kamien (U. Penn.) presented the topological defects in liquid crystals as well as knotting behavior in knitting.  With 25 contributed speakers, this was another large session, and attracted participants working in materials science areas usually not represented at this conference. This session not only covered inorganic materials but also a gamut of nanocarbons for energy and photonics, polymers and liquid crystals as well as biological systems such as proteins and DNA, where topology and geometry are intertwined and play important role in influencing their physical properties for wide ranging applications. Speakers came from several countries (Japan, China, Poland, etc.), several Ivy Leagues schools, and National Labs (ORNL, LANL, NIST etc.) in the US.
